definition: a neglected branch (of arts, science, sports etc)/fig. a complete unknown who wins a competition

gate/door/CL:扇[shan4]/gateway/doorway/CL:個|个[ge4]/opening/valve/switch/way to do something/knack/family/house/(religious) sect/school (of thought)/class/category/phylum or division (taxonomy)/classifier for large guns/classifier for lessons, subjects, branches of technology/(suffix) -gate (i.e. scandal; derived from Watergate)
an upset (esp. in sports)/unexpected turn of events/to pull off a coup/a breakthrough
erhua variant of 爆冷門|爆冷门[bao4 leng3 men2]

sentences.english: Way too often what is hot this year won't be hot a few years from now.
sentences.chinese: 今年热门的行业几年后很可能会成冷门，这是常事。

sentences.english: However, it wasn't until the fourth ever World Cup that the first upset occured.
sentences.chinese: 然而，直到第四届世界杯才出现了第一个真正的冷门。

sentences.english: There was almost an upset in the finals of the men's floor exercise.
sentences.chinese: 男子自由体操决赛几乎爆出冷门。

sentences.english: The winning horse was a rank outsider.
sentences.chinese: 获胜的马是一匹完全不起眼儿的冷门马。

sentences.english: This year's Gold Horse Award had a really unexpected winner.
sentences.chinese: 今年的金马奖爆了个大冷门。

sentences.english: There were many unexpected results during the World Shortcourse Swimming Championships in Sweden .
sentences.chinese: 在瑞典举行的世界短池游泳锦标赛中爆出了许多冷门。

definition: an upset (esp. in sports)/unexpected turn of events/to pull off a coup/a breakthrough
minority of the population/non-mainstream (activity, pursuit etc)/niche (market etc)
an upset (esp. in sports)/unexpected turn of events/to pull off a coup/a breakthrough
chicken ribs/sth of little value or interest/sth of dubious worth that one is reluctant to give up/to be physically weak
to try to answer a question (in a quiz, guessing game, riddle etc)/quiz game
old, well-known brand/old style/old school/an old hand/experienced veteran
to regard as having good prospects
